topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Bob Moesta’s new book Job Moves and tees up key ideas: career progress, “jobcation,” and the difference between job features and job experiences. Bob frames the book’s goal as helping people find better-fitting work by understanding themselves.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Eppo (experimentation/A-B testing platform) and Vanta (security compliance automation), including product overviews and listener discount.

topics.title: Why Job Moves: solving the talent problem
topics.summary: Bob explains why he wrote Job Moves: talent is a persistent founder pain, and most job switchers end up worse off because they don’t understand what they need. He argues the book may be more impactful than JTBD due to the sheer scale of job changes.

topics.title: Big idea: employees hire companies
topics.summary: Bob describes the core thesis: people attribute good job moves to luck, but “luck = opportunity + preparedness.” The goal is to help individuals prepare, clarify progress, and “hire” their job daily to avoid stagnation.

topics.title: Job features vs job experiences
topics.summary: They unpack why experiences (not features like salary/title) drive retention and satisfaction. Bob explains money as a proxy for deeper needs (respect, security, status) and emphasizes understanding the “why” behind feature desires.

topics.title: The four quests behind leaving a job
topics.summary: Bob shares findings from “ultimate exit interviews”: pushes and pulls cluster into four quests—Get Out, Take the Next Step, Regain Control, and Realign. Understanding your quest helps aim the job search toward the right kind of progress.

topics.title: Why diagnosing pushes and pulls matters
topics.summary: Bob explains job changes aren’t random: context and accumulated pushes create enough energy to move, but pulls provide direction. Without clear pulls, people either stay stuck or switch into similar/worse roles.

topics.title: Energy drivers and drains: finding your requirements
topics.summary: Bob outlines how to identify energizing and draining moments across past roles to extract personal “design requirements” for work. He argues many people spend most time on draining tasks, and improving that ratio can transform satisfaction.

topics.title: Quick exercises and common examples
topics.summary: They discuss lightweight ways to start: recall recent energizing/draining moments, reflect daily after meetings, and dig beneath surface preferences (e.g., “the beach”) to causal drivers. Bob gives examples like learning, helping others, and routine as person-dependent.

topics.title: Job design, AI help, and team complementarity
topics.summary: Bob argues job descriptions are often made up and mismatched; better outcomes come from shaping roles around strengths and offloading drains (potentially with AI/process). He also highlights building teams with complementary opposites rather than clones.

topics.title: Prototyping your next job with informational interviews
topics.summary: For job seekers, Bob recommends treating career moves like product discovery: distill strengths/energy patterns, prototype widely across industries, and run informational interviews to test fit before applying. This builds clarity and practice talking about yourself.

topics.title: Aiming your search: quests plus requirements
topics.summary: They restate the combined framework: pushes create momentum, quests provide direction, and energy/strength requirements refine targeting. Bob emphasizes aligning the job to the person rather than forcing the person to fit a generic description.

topics.title: Trade-offs, compensation, and progress over perfection
topics.summary: Bob explains no job checks every box; success comes from explicit trade-offs (e.g., money vs learning) and timeboxing choices. They discuss when optimizing for salary/title can make sense, how better experiences can offset pay, and why overpaying can create risk-averse behavior.
